Message.Title: Why Amzn refuses to go down?
Message.Msg: It seems Amzn is defying logic and refuses to go down. The reason is simple in short term. Most investors are switching out of active mutual funds and into index ETFs. Since most active managers are under-weighting AMZN against index, it is reasonable to see AMZN has sightly out-performed QQQ. However, over long term, fundamental will decides its fate.

Message.Title: Amazon's no show on sustainability
Message.Msg: Just try to find Amazon's sustainability report. You can't. There's no such thing. As far as anyone can tell, Amazon has made little or no effort to measure, disclose or improve its performance when it comes to the environment, workplace issues, diversity, charitable giving or political activity. This puts it behind rivals such as Walmart and Best Buy, technology giants Microsoft and Google and logistics and shipping firms UPS and FedEx. Indeed, it is fair to say that when it comes to corporate responsibility, as the term is commonly understood, Amazon is a no-show. Consider, for example, the company's environmental record. This month, a non-profit group called Climate Counts scored the world's largest companies on their climate impact: Amazon ranked near the bottom of the list (127 out of 145), as it has since the rankings began in 2007. Amazon has declined to disclose its greenhouse gas emissions or climate strategy to the Carbon Disclosure Project; this year, 81% of corporations (405 companies) from the Global S&P 500 responded to the project's questionnaire. When Greenpeace examined data centres run by big technology companies in a report called How Clean Is Your Cloud?, Amazon was given an F in three of four categories, ranking behind Yahoo!, Dell, Google and Facebook. On electronics recycling, Amazon is also a laggard. Best Buy takes back electronic waste, at no charge; Amazon does no take-back of its own. The company, which employs more than 50,000 people, has also been assailed for mistreating workers in its warehouses. A 2011 investigation into working conditions at a Pennsylvania warehouse by The Morning Call newspaper found that workers were "forced to endure brutal heat inside the sprawling warehouse and were pushed to work at a pace many could not sustain". Some were carried from the building on stretchers when the heat topped 100F. Earlier, workers at warehouse in the UK said they were being penalised for taking sick days and made to work seven days a week. And, as long ago as 2001, the company was accused of running "the worst of old economy working practices" by staff in the UK, the Guardian reported. There's much more. Amazon has vigorously fought state governments that tried to collect sales taxes. Amazon will sell about $60bn (£37bn) worth of goods this year. When South Carolina declined to exempt Amazon from collecting the state's 6% sales tax on purchases by people in the state, the company stopped building a warehouse and prepared to leave, throwing thousands of jobs into jeopardy, according to the Seattle Times. Locally, its reputation isn't great, either. The newspaper last spring described Amazon as "a minor player – at best – in local charitable giving" and said the company "cuts an astoundingly low profile in the civic life of its hometown".

Message.Title: William Blair Study
Message.Msg: Let's try again... I found the William Blair study amusing. I would hope that TGT and WMT charge more than Amazon for products and categories where it is more cost effective to deliver in store (and would explain why their in store prices are higher than online). Everyone sees what they want to see. I suspect TGT and WMT understand the relative economics of online versus physical better than Amazon.

Topic.Title: William Blair Study

Message.Msg: Again, this relates to the point I have made about the TCO. Amazon undercutting on price DOES NOT MEAN that it is profitably serving those customers on those products/categories. One of the main levers WMT and TGT has is to NOT match prices on low value density items and match on high value density hard goods. Let consumers order all the low value density from Amazon. Factor in the economics of delivery and let Amazon bear all those cost (since it gives shipping away to everyone). Amazon will end up eating massive losses on the shipping that dwarf the margin realized... TGT, WMT and traditional retail can turn the "e-commerce" economics on its head through strategic pricing.

Message.Title: Similarities between ENRON and AMAZON
Message.Msg: Let the list begin: -Crazy Valuation -Entering a New Market every other Day - sometimes to hide current realities. -Could not deliver real Earnings -Enron and Amazon rhyme. A little help please.

Topic.Title: Similarities between ENRON and AMAZON

Message.Msg: Much as I do not like Amazon, nor the malinvestment that it continues, Amazon is no Enron. Amazon is doing what NFLX and GMCR did. Take advantage of the virtually zero cost of capital to build the biggest footprint possible. It will undoubtedly be worth more even if it crashes now than it would be been three or four years ago (even though that number is no more than $100 a share). That, of course, is the momentum game. Good for original institutional investors, bad for anyone to jump in as it approaches the "delivery" phase from the "story" phase.

Topic.Title: William Blair Study

Message.Msg: I'm an Amazon Prime member and I’m also short the stock (but hedged with covered Puts). Amazon Prime is a steal to consumers, similar to how Netflix was before it jacked up the price. It was even more of a steal before they started charging sales tax. There is no way Amazon makes money on its Amazon Prime customers. I order a few times a month a few items per order. I don’t order until I have at least three things in my basket, because I want to give Amazon the opportunity to bundles the delivery. But they almost never do. Invariably, I get one package for each item. The delivery costs have to be eating them up. The streaming is pretty good. I only watch the free movies, but my daughter pays for a TV show about once a week, so they are making some money from us that way.

Topic.Title: Similarities between ENRON and AMAZON

Message.Msg: Having said that, I do find it remarkable that analysts give Amazon such a free pass. They killed Google, even though it generates massive cash flow. There are several signs that cash flow is not good (killing monthly Prime, debt offering, etc). Retailers are now matching price. They need to take it to the next level and develop a pricing strategy that creates a selection bias for consumers to buy high shipping cost relative to product margin from Amazon. Coupled with the price competition from Google on AWS, Amazon will certainly feel a crunch in 2013, despite what all the pumpers say...

Topic.Title: And Why did this #$%$ go up again today??

Message.Msg: WS is trying to convince everyone (and itself) that we are at risk of significant inflation. We aren't. Not even close. But, the past few weeks have been a test to see if retail investors can be compelled into the market with incessant messaging of the bond bubble. It won't work. As I've said many times, trust is absolutely broken. Retail investors will take the interest rate risk on short term treasuries... Taking AAPL down while propping this up is just another example of trying to screw retail investors (buying an overvalued Amazon and shaking out weak retail longs in AAPL) and people have learned. When the games end and WS revert to real world relative valuations (even if a little bubbly), then retail might come back. Also, a bunch of fuzzy thinking institutions are holding this as part of a "barbell" strategy to protect against inflation with growth. Needless to say, as an investment, Amazon fails the barbell criteria on so many levels it is hard to cover all of them. But, Amazon is most certainly NOT an "inflation" hedge. In fact, any real inflation will fundamentally undermine Amazon's competitiveness... At some point, people will be clearer by what we mean by "inflation". When they start thinking clearly, they will realize that Amazon is an epic disaster of an "inflation".

It would take Amazon 3,100 years of earnings to equal its market price, and a 100 years plus its forward PE.
